page.title: 15HACKENSALL FARM
page.content: The Baines family first came to live in Knott End in 1925 when Mr Baines' uncle found some Roman coins on the golf links. Since then the family has lived at Hackensall Farm and also owns New Heys Farm, S.E. of Knott End. The farm consists of 200 acres, with 44% acreage of corn. They grow barley and grass and have 60 milk calves and 90 beef calves. The feed merchants buy their crops but in the winter they feed all their own animals. Machinery consists of milking machine, ploughs, 2 tractors, harrows, seed drills, a combine harvester and manure spreader. The trees round the farm used to have lumps on the bark, but when the power station was closed down the lumps disappeared.The barn, once a chapel, now has a barn owl! Michael, a friend, rings bluetits and chaffinches and builds nesting-boxes in the woods.
